Nanocarbon materials play a critical role in the development of new or improved technologies and devices for sustainable production and use of renewable energy. This perspective paper defines some of the trends and outlooks in this exciting area, with the effort of evidencing some of the possibilities offered from the growing level of knowledge, as testified from the exponentially rising number of publications, and putting bases for a more rational design of these nanomaterials. The basic members of the new carbon family are fullerene, graphene, and carbon nanotube. Derived from them are carbon quantum dots, nanohorn, nanofiber, nano ribbon, nanocapsulate, nanocage and other nanomorphologies. Second generation nanocarbons are those which have been modified by surface functionalization or doping with heteroatoms to create specific tailored properties. The third generation of nanocarbons is the nanoarchitectured supramolecular hybrids or composites of the first and second generation nanocarbons, or with organic or inorganic species. The advantages of the new carbon materials, relating to the field of sustainable energy, are discussed, evidencing the unique properties that they offer for developing next generation solar devices and energy storage solutions. Introduction The current energy supply to our society is based on fossil fuels to a great extent, but their reserve will be depleted in a near future and there is the need to limit their use to control greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. There is thus a general consensus on the need to have a well-considered roadmap for a change of the future energy scenario, with the final goal of replacing fossil energy by renewable energies [1] (Figure 1 ). On a short term, fossil fuel energy remains the only energy source world-wide, but the efficiency needs to be increased and the carbon dioxide emission must be drastically decreased. The newly reported shale gas fields in US, Europe and China with enormously potential reserve volume are exciting (even if there are many concerns), but the impact on environment and GHG emissions is very high. Looking for alternative and renewable energies could be the only solution for the sustainable development of our society. Research activities in numerous laboratories worldwide are laying the foundation for the future energy scenario, but the current challenge regards the development of new tailored (nano) materials which are needed to enable a sustainable use of renewable sources of energy. Carbon materials play a key role in this perspective. A non-fossil based future energy scenario consists of two major parts: energy conversion and energy storage. Although different sources of renewable energy will play a role, solar energy will be the dominant one in a long-term energy scenario [2]. The implementation of this scenario infers the need to develop efficient and cost-competitive devices to convert solar energy in a form suitable for use in actual energy infrastructure to minimize the already high investment costs necessary in changing from the present energy system [1]. Therefore, it is necessary not only to improve devices to convert sunlight to electrical energy, passing from current photovoltaic systems to those of the 3rd and 4th generation, but also to develop systems to store more efficiently electrical energy as well as devices to convert sunlight in a form directly usable in actual infrastructure, eg., to produce solar fuel [3–5] through hydrogenation of carbon dioxide or production of hydrogen by water photoelectrolysis. Effective coupling of energy conversion and storage systems realizing smart grids is a great challenge which must be addressed through new concepts, materials, processes and technologies [6,7]. Carbon materials only play a limited role in a fossil-fuel dominated energy scenario, but their importance is increasing progressively in moving to this new energy scenario and the need of our society for a distributed and transportable high-density energy. Graphite is the most used anode materials in commercialized lithium ion batteries. Activated carbon remains the only active materials for supercapacitors, and carbon black the support for electrocatalysts in fuel cells. All these are energy conversion and storage devices that can be transferred into a solar energy-based future energy scenario, however, their performances are below the requirements for a non-fossil energy based society in which not only cellar phone, laptop or cars but also power station, long-distance transport, lighting and heating need to be powered. This future energy scenario is the driving force for current activities in carbon materials research for energy application (Figure 2 ). The motivations for the choice of carbon are many: carbon is cheaper, abundant, environmentally friendly, and carbon, with its various bonding states and allotropes, allows derivation of a family of new carbon materials, the basis of the so-called nanocarbon science. These nanocarbon materials are foreseen to play a special role in the future energy scenario that the classical carbon cannot have [8–13]. Comparing to conventional energy materials, carbon nanomaterials possess unique size/surface-dependent (e.g., morphology, electrical, optical, and mechanical) properties that allow a step-forward in enhancing the energy-conversion and storage performances. This perspective paper, introduced in the special issue of this journal, is dedicating to this topic, and will define some of the trends and outlooks in this exciting area, in the effort to evidence from one side some of the possibilities offered from the growing level of knowledge testified from the exponentially rising number of publications (Figure 2), and on the other hand put the bases for a more rational design of these nanomaterials. 2. Nanocarbon material generations, their features and advantages The basic members of the new carbon family are fullerene, graphene, and carbon nanotube (CNTs). Derived from them are carbon quantum dots, nanohorn, nanofiber, nano ribbon, nanocapsulate, nanocage and other nanomorphology. We may call all these nanocarbons with simple morphology the first generation of nanocarbons. The common advantage of the new carbon materials are their low dimension, specific morphology and morphology-defined properties. All sp 2-hybridization derived nanocarbons are well ordered and possess long-range ordering, but they differ from the classical bulk graphite. The nano-dimension with specific morphology gives them physical and chemical properties that other classical carbons do not have: high electroconductivity, good thermal conductivity, and outstanding mechanical properties. An important characteristic of these new carbon materials is the possibility to tailor their electronic structures by introducing heteroatoms, to adapt their physical properties by controlling the pore structures, and to change their chemical properties by introducing functional groups on the surface. In this way it is possible to introduce a level of control in the characteristics of these materials not possible in other systems. We may define these modified carbon materials as the second generation of nanocarbons, albeit the study, preparation and characterisation of these nanocarbons have been proceeded usually in parallel with the development of the first generation nanocarbons. These characteristics, together with the other cited properties, and the possibility to produce them today in a cost-competitive way on large scale, make unique carbon nanomaterials for the use in the very challenging area of sustainable energy applications possible [7,10,11]. Another important characteristic of the new carbon materials is the possibility to design and build hybrid or hierarchical materials [14]. We define these nano-architectural materials as the third generation of nanocarbons (Figure 3 ). An interesting example, with great interest to develop improved systems for producing solar fuels, is given from TiO2-nanocarbons (CNTs, graphene, etc.) hybrids [15,16]. Figure 4 shows an example of TiO2 nanoparticles over graphene acting as electron acceptor to enhance charge separation and improve the performance of TiO2 in water photoelectrolysis. Nanocarbons can also act as electron donors, i.e. photosensitisers (carbon quantum dots), as will be discussed later. In addition, the intrinsic properties of TiO2 are changed by this interaction with nanocarbons, creating hybrid materials [15,16]. The advantages of nanomaterials in photochemical applications are manifold [16–20]. The nanocarbons can 1) transfer electrons into an inorganic compound and act as a photosensitiser in extending the absorption range; 2) accept photoexcited electrons from the inorganic compound, thus separating them from the photoactive holes; 3) conduct away excess heat during the catalytic reaction; 4) act as a template and heat sink to stabilise smaller catalyst particles whose larger specific surface area can convert more reactant molecules; and 5) reduce the amount of active catalyst, decrease their weight and improve cycling ability and overall life time. In most cases, the obtained hybrid or composite materials with hierarchical structures have a strong synergistic effect in combining the advantage of the two building blocks. Another kind of third generation nanocarbons is carboncarbon hybrids composed of different types of nanocarbons (Figure 3) that are also significantly growing in importance for the design of advanced nanomaterials for sustainable energy. For example, zero-, one-, and two-dimensional nanostructured carbon allotropes, i.e., fullerenes, SWCNTs and graphenes in combination with electron-donating conjugated molecules are promising building blocks for artificial photosynthesis and solar energy conversion [21]. In porphyrin-fullerene linked dyads, efficient photoinduced electron transfer occurs to yield charge-separated states in competition with the decay of the excited states to the ground state (Figure 5 ). Moderate length-spacers between the donor (porphyrin) and the acceptor (fullerenes) are essential to produce a long-lived charge-separated state efficiently. However, in a solid material or when these dyads are deposited over a surface, intermolecular direct quenching between different dyads dominates the overall performances, if not a highly diluted system is realized. The use of these systems requires thus to create a superstructure which avoids/minimizes from one side these effects, allowing at the same time a high density of dyads to improve productivity and overall performance. One of the possibilities is to realize supramolecular hybridization of SWCNT with fullerenes (Figure 5c) [21]. SWCNT can act as both electron-acceptor and -donor in the SWCNT-fullerene composites, and also act as efficient wire on charge-transporting properties. In this way, devices could be realized having well dispersed linked dyads (minimizing their direct interaction) over a substrate using SWCNTs as the backbone and at the same time wire to improve the electrical communication between the dyads and the collecting substrate [21]. Even if efforts are still necessary for a better understanding of how to realize an optimal design and minimize the many possible interfaces which reduce the efficiency, it is evident that this is one of the exciting directions to develop new artificial photosynthesis devices and solar cells. Another interesting possibility is the development of advanced Z-schemes for water splitting [22]. One of the main approaches for achieving water splitting using visible light is to apply a two-step photoexcitation mechanism between two different photocatalysts (Figure 6a ). This process was inspired by natural photosynthesis in green plants and is known as the Z-scheme. In the two-step systems, the water splitting reaction is broken up into two stages: one for H2 evolution and the other for O2 evolution; these are combined by using a shuttle redox couple (Red/Ox, for example the I3 −/I− pair) in the solution. Over a H2 evolution photocatalyst, the photoexcited electrons reduce water to H2 and holes in the valence band oxidize the reductant (Red) to an oxidant (Ox). The oxidant is reduced back to the reductant by photoexcited electrons generated over an O2 evolution photocatalyst, where the holes oxidize water to O2. This system lowers the energy required for photocatalysis, allowing visible light to be utilized more efficiently than in conventional water-splitting systems. The use of solutions has a number of practical problems when realizing solar cells (sealing, light scattering, etc.). A recent interesting development is based on the use of photoreduced graphene oxide as a solid electron mediator for water splitting in the Z-scheme photocatalysis system (Figure 6b) [23]. The graphene sheet can shuttle photogenerated electrons from an O2-evolving photocatalyst (BiVO4) to a H2-evolving photocatalyst (Ru/SrTiO3:Rh), triplicating the consumption of electron-hole pairs in the water splitting reaction under visible-light irradiation. Even though the overall performance is still unsatisfactory (about 8–10 mmol H2/h in H2SO4 aqueous solution using a 300 W Xe lamp as light source with a 420 nm cut-off filter), the example shows the potential to use advanced hybrid nanoarchitectures based on nanocarbons for producing solar fuels. This kind of 3rd generation carbon materials, derived from the basic nanocarbon blocks (fullerene, graphene, CNTs) or produced by templating or by combining with inorganic nanoblocks [24,25], may be predicted to have a great potential for energy applications. Currently, CNTs account for a 28% market share of overall demand for nanomaterials. In terms of production capacity, Asia-Pacific is leading, followed by North America and the European Union. There are thus bright future expectations for the nanocarbon market in the field of energy and related devices. However, there are a number of aspects relating to interface and optimal nanodesign that have to be understood and better analysed to consolidate and further expand the market opportunities. Up to now a large part of the effort was still dedicated to prepare them and analyse the performances, often obtaining results below the real potential of these systems. It is thus definitely necessary to have a more knowledge-based design approach to these nanomaterials. 3. Key characteristics of nanocarbons for energy applications A number of characteristics of nanocarbons render them attracting materials for energy applications: • High surface area: These materials could have very high specific surface area [27]. For instance, the specific surface of graphene is as high as 2700 m2/g, and SWCNT 1350 m2/g. The templated hierarchical carbon can easily have a surface area larger than 2000 m2/g [28,29]. • Tuneable pore structure: CNTs have a unique monodimensional pore structure defined by the inner diameter that within some extend can be changed by varying the synthesis conditions. Dual pore structure can be obtained by template synthesis [30]. Nanocarbons in carbon materials can be prepared by CVD [31], hierarchical CNT-graphene hybrid nanostructure, in which the graphene layers are distributed inside the CNT inner cavities, can also be prepared by CVD methods [32], as well as CNF be possibly grown inside large CNTs [33]. Zeolite-templated carbons (ZTCs) can have uniformly ordered micropores as small as 1.2 nm and surface areas up to over 4000 m2/g [34]. ZTCs have a structure made up of buckybowl-like nanographenes assembled into a three-dimensionally regular network [35] (Figure 7a and b ). By tailoring the pore alignment it is possible to obtain exceptionally fast ion transport properties in these materials [36]. Due to this unique pore structure, ZTCs possess high-performance in electric double layer capacitor [37] and for H2 storage [38]. On the other hand, by using other silica templates (mesoporous materials and silica colloidal nanosphere) it is possible to obtain different ordered porous structures, with mono-or 3D-channels or pore structures, and the dimension of the channels or pre up to over 100 nm) (Figure 7c and d) [39]. These examples illustrate the unique variety of possible pore structures which can be obtained in nanocarbon materials, which do not find correspondence in other kind of nanomaterials. • High electron, phonon and heat transport: Many nanocarbons have a faster and more efficient electron, phonon and heat transport with respect to their bulk counterparts such as activated carbon or carbon black [16]. Theoretical predictions yield an extremely high thermal conductivity for individual SWCNTs, e.g. k of about 6600 W·m−1 K−1 [40], but the effective values in nanotube assemblies are lower over one order of magnitude due to various reasons [41]: quenching of phonon modes in bundles reinforced by radial deformation of carbon nanotubes by van der Waals forces (phonon modes contribute to the heat flow), tube-tube interconnections and sheet imperfections like dangling fiber ends, loops and misalignment of nanotubes, and impurities and structural irregularities in nanotubes inducing multiple elastic scattering of electrons. Nanotube junctions as well as nanotube quality have thus a greater impact on heat and electron transport and dissipation [42]. Although CNTs show potential electrical and thermal transport in the ballistic regime, the effective electrical and thermal performances are lower, even though still better than those of activated carbon. However, there is a lack of investigation in how the quality of nanocarbons and the presence of multiple junctions affect the charge transport, heat transport and dissipation, phonon scattering, in relation to the use of these nanomaterials for developing solar cells and energy storage devices. This is an area which needs more attention in order to define the preferable design in the materials. • Easy accessibility for reactant or ions: Due to the small size and the specific morphology, the reactant/product in a chemical reaction or the charged particles (ions or protons) can be better transported to the active sites in an electrochemical process with respect to conventional carbon materials. There is a general agreement of the need of a hierarchical design for carbon-based nanostructures in applications such as in electrochemical energy storage, conversion and biosensor [43]. Carbon-based nanocomposites with hierarchical structures have a nanoarchitecture that provides large internal surface area, excellent conductance as well as synergistic effects for electrochemical reactions at the interface. However, this design is often still qualitative and phenomenological, and a general rationalization for the design of the best nanoarchitectures in relation to the different uses is still lacking. • New storage mechanism: the small size and the specific morphology in nanocarbons provide new mechanisms for the storage of lithium ions (Figure 8 ), or Faradaic reaction for charge storage (pseudocapacity) [44]. Lithium can be stored in CNTs in different modes (Figure 8a) [45]: (i) intercalation in the well graphitized part of multiwall CNTs, (ii) adsorption and accumulation on the outside of the surface, (iii) in the inner channels of the tubular structure in the form of either ions, atoms, or charged clusters in the case of opened CNTs, (iv) in the vacancy between normally entangled tubes and (v) in the form of intercalation and adsorption in/on the graphitic or amorphous carbon impurity in CNT materials. The Li storage capacity may be extended using these different possibilities of Li storage, by creating nanocarbon-nanocarbon hybrid nanostructures, for example CNFs (carbon nanofibres) encapsulated within CNTs (CNFs@CNTs) [33]. The hybrid of nanocarbons with metals oxides (e.g. Ni, V, etc.) that react with lithium can be also realized to boost the specific capacity with respect to that of conventional intercalation reactions. By realizing highly dispersed and small nanoparticle sized metal oxides, it is possible to minimize the stress relating to volume changes during the alloying/de-alloying processes with Li, which would cause critical mechanical damage to the electrode, resulting in a marked loss of capacity with time [43]. By optimizing these factors in the design of nanocarbon hybrids it is possible to realize very high electrochemical performances in Li storage. These systems are indicated as lithium ion capacitors (LICs), e.g. an intermediate system between lithium ion batteries and supercapacitors to take advantage of both types of energy storage systems. A recent example is by Shin et al. [46] that have developed NiO dispersed over defective N-doped MWCNTs as stable, high performance Li-storage materials. Nitrogen-doped CNTs contain wall defects through which lithium ions can diffuse, so as to occupy a large portion of the interwall space as storage regions. When integrated with 3 nm nickel oxide nanoparticles for a further capacity boost, nitrogen doping enables unprecedented cell performance by engaging anomalous electrochemical phenomena such as nanoparticle division into even smaller ones, their agglomeration-free diffusion between nitrogen-doped sites as well as capacity rise with cycles. The final cells exhibit a capacity as high as 3500 mAh/g, a cycle life of greater than 10000 times, and a discharge rate capability of 1.5 min while retaining a capacity of 350 mAh/g. Also in the use as supercapacitors carbon materials evidence that the nanodimension brings new aspects which can be successfully used to develop high performance storage materials for energy applications. A supercapacitor, or an electric double layer capacitor (EDLC), is a device that stores charge electrostatically through reversible adsorption of ions of the electrolyte onto active materials that are electrochemically stable and expose a high surface area. However, there are no simple relations between the surface area and the performances [47]. The normalized capacitance (per m2 of surface area) decreases nearly linearly with the decreasing of the average pore size up to about 1.5 nm, according to the electrochemical double-layer charge Helmholtz model. However, there is an exponential increase below this threshold due to distortion of the ion solvation shell and partial desolvation of the ions, which enables the ions to access pores of a size equal to or slightly larger than the size of the bare ion [48]. The ions can be thus stacked into the subnanometric pores along the pore axis. This is actually a new charge storage mechanism, since ions are confined in a situation very close to intercalation/insertion, which is a new mechanism to explain the charge storage in electrochemical capacitors based on nanoporous carbons. These examples show that the nanodimension in carbon materials introduces new properties that can be critical for the design of new improved systems of energy conversion and storage. • Confinement for active phase: the finite space of CNTs or porous carbon can hold active particles, molecules and even atoms [49–51], change their properties (for example, with respect to the case when they are present on the external surface of the CNTs). There is thus an influence on the performances of these materials either with respect to reactivity and/or ion/charge storage. The reasons for the confinement effect, however, are still not fully understood. The inner space of nanocarbons can also be used to constrain the volumetric expansion of the active phase during charging/discharging. This is a very specific but critical problem when using inorganic materials for lithium ions storage in high rate and power density batteries [51]. Another confinement effect is related to the modification of physical or chemical properties of molecules in a confined space. This is an aspect important for catalysis, but also for electrochemical and other applications. Compared with the fluids in the bulk phase, the transport properties of molecules (water, for example) inside the CNTs can be largely enhanced, e.g. the opposite of what is expected for diffusion limitations [52]. Methanol molecules inside CNTs may be organized in the form of a monowire, in which the molecules are one-dimensionally hydrogen-bonded [53]. Significant deviations in fluid properties can be present in confined nanochannels [54]. How these changed properties interact with or influence the catalytic reaction in the confined space of the CNTs, however, is still to be explored. Another confinement effect that is not well studied is the modification of the size and shape of the particles in a CNT. Until now, studies on the confinement assume that the shape and size of the nanoparticles inside or outside the CNTs do not differ with each other. A recent work shows that the confinement effect also affects the size and shape of cobalt based nanoparticles inside the CNTs [55]. Zheng et al. [56] suggest that the inner walls of CNTs may have less ordered graphitic degree, such that formation of smaller, less faceted and more defective Ru nanoparticles compared with those formed on the outsurface of a CNT resulted. 4. Factors facilitating the use of nanocarbon materials in energy research and open issues As outlined in the previous sections, more than two decades of research have made a substantial development in the field of the synthesis of nanocarbon materials and the control of their properties, while understanding of their structure-reactivity-properties relationships is starting only more recently, and there is still lack of bases for their rational design in relation to the different types of applications in the field of sustainable energy. For this reason, it is useful to summarize here the major aspects to take into consideration for a realistic use of new nanocarbon materials in the future energy scenario: i. The methods for doping nanocarbons with heteroatoms to change the electronic/chemical properties are well established, and detailed understanding of how the doping reflects in the change of surface functionalities and properties is in the growing. However, the control of homogeneity of the properties at the level of individual elements is still lacking, for example, between different CNTs in a single batch. ii. A broad protocol for covalent and non-covalent functionalization of nanocarbons is available. However, more attention should be given to understand the cost-effectiveness of some of the functionalization procedures as well as the long-term stability of the materials under practical operations. iii. The assembling of low-dimensional nanocarbons into three-dimensional architectures (films, hollow spherical capsulates, aligned arrays or helical arrays), i.e., the third generation of nanocarbons, is well demonstrated, albeit engineering such 3D structures in scalable synthetic processes still remains a challenge. The issue of understanding how the many interfaces are created and influence the overall properties have to be investigated and understood in more detail. iv. Mass production of CNTs, one of the most representatives of nanocarbons, is industrialized. CNTs with reasonable prices are now available. This is one of the prerequisites for broad applications of the nanocarbons. However, it is still necessary to produce at the level of homogeneity and reproducibility of these mass-production samples as well as in using these materials as building blocks to prepare cost-competitive and more complex carbon nanostructures. v. Techniques for the characterization of nanocarbons, from very high local resolution to the observation of dynamics, are applicable and available in many laboratories. However, characterization is often limited to few aspects. There are many aspects, such as the type of defects, the nanocarbon-nanocarbon and nanocarbon-metal particles interfaces in hybrid materials, the surface transport of species, the interface with other elements in devices (membranes in fuel cells, for example), which play a significant role in determining the reactivity and functional properties of nanocarbon-based materials, are not systematically investigated. The range of techniques to evaluate the reactivity and functional performances of these materials is also expanding, but more effort is necessary in going beyond the phenomenological investigation of these materials. 5. Carbon materials for energy storage Renewable energy is only sustainable on large-scale and can only be integrated into current energy infrastructures when cost-effective and high-capacity storage technologies are developed. Large-scale electrical energy storage is necessary to couple intermittent renewable energy production to a smart electrical grid. For the automobile sector, there must be enough energy storage to allow a competitive use with respect to current engines based on fossil energy fuels. For long-distance transport of renewable energy, storage is also critical. Stationary energy storage includes applications that range from kW to MW and GW systems (Figure 9a ) [57]. The storage, the discharge time and the power/energy ratio are much larger than for the transportation sector, in particular for plug-in hybrid electrical (PHEVs) and fully electrical vehicles (EVs). The latter requires tens of kW power and needs a response (discharge) time over tens of seconds. The cost of PHEV storage can be higher than in stationary power applications, and higher than energy applications in stationary storage (Figure 9b). There is no single technology or a single target that is universal for different applications, but electrochemical energy storage is currently the most versatile technology, because of its flexibility to cover wide energy and time domains [57]. Batteries and electrochemical capacitors must be developed for high energy density and high power applications (for example, ultrafast charge under 30 mile/min) in cars and frequency regulation on grids. Smart grids are another future important area for these devices. A Smart Grid, according to the U. S. Department of Energy in its Grid 2030 vision, is “a 21st century electric system that connects everyone to abundant, affordable, clean, efficient, and reliable electric power anytime, anywhere”. A number of different technologies have to be developed to implement this concept, including the realization of efficiently distributed energy storage, to be realized with new chemical batteries and ultracapacitors. This vision does not include the conversion of electrical to chemical energy (for example, through electrolyzers) or in a longer term the direct solar energy conversion to chemical energy (solar fuels, for example methanol or higher alcohols produced from CO2, water and sunlight [2,5]). These aspects will be discussed later in relation to the use of nanocarbons materials for energy conversion. We, instead, summarize here the current trends in the use of nanocarbons for energy storage devices. 5.1. Li-ion batteries The lithium ion battery (LiB) is the most successful achievement of electrochemical energy storage, evidenced by the millions of pieces produced every year for mobile applications. However, no current Li-ion battery can be used for electrical vehicles (EV) or grid regulation. For transportation, the goal for the US Department of Energy (DOE) and the automobile industry is to develop batteries with an energy density of 300 Wh/l and 250 Wh/kg and with a cost of $125/kWh in order to enable the 300-miles range midsize sedan. Conventional cathode materials using lithium salts, such as LiCoO2, LiMn2O4, and LiFePO4, usually have 140–170 mAh/g capacity, while conventional graphite-based anode has a theoretical capacity of 372 mAh/g. Improvement in the performance of cathode materials and storage capacitance is a key aspect to improve the performance of Li-ion batteries. A few alternatives to the above mentioned lithium salts have been developed. Among these are layered or spinel-type compounds [58] showing promising, but still not satisfying performance for EV application or grid regulation. Apart from the low energy and power density of the current batteries, two other major challenges are the safety issue and cost. The latter is not so critical a parameter for small batteries of portable applications, but a determining aspect for large scale applications. Cost is not only related to the type of raw materials used and the production technology, but also to the performances which can be obtained, in turn evidencing the need of better electrode materials. While nanocarbons cannot be used as cathode materials of a Li-ion battery, research has shown that they could be a good conductive additive for the cathode to improve high rate performance and thus increase the power density [59]. Nanocarbons facilitate the conduction of charged species in the cathode materials and help also to disperse the negative charge accumulation which may otherwise impede Li-ion diffusion within the cathodes. Highly pure CNTs have been used in some industrial product of Li-ions battery for portable application, while their use as additive for EV batteries with more strict requirements needs to be further explored and optimized. Due to the intrinsic properties of inorganic compounds with bad or no conductivity, the addition of nanocarbons seems to be the only way to have a facial electron transport, and thus to exhibit high rate performance. On the anode side of the Li-ion batteries, graphite is the material of choice for most Li-ion chemistry. It has a theoretical capacity of 372 Ah/kg, but an observed capacity of 280–330 Ah/kg depending on the type and/or source of the graphite. First and second generation nanocarbon materials have been tested as alternative anode materials [7]. They show interesting performance relating to high surface area, porous structure, new storage mechanism and good conductivity. Nevertheless, their performances are not good enough for EC or grid applications. Alternative alloys and/or intermetallic materials, such as Si (4, 200 mAh/g), Sn (992 mAh/g), or SnO2 (782 mAh/g) based anodes, have been extensively investigated as options for high specific capacity. Insertion, alloying or conversion are the reaction mechanisms by which these alternative electrode materials operate, different from lithium batteries that based on the mechanism of intercalation of lithium ions. This change in operating mechanism makes a high potential capacity possible, but brings additional problems that need to be solved for practical applications. For instance, Si is a promising candidate because of its high theoretical capacity and low discharge potential [60,61], but there are at least three mechanisms causing the failure of the Si anode: • mechanical instability caused by cracking and pulverizing of the Si material, • loss of electrical contacts among the Si particles and between the active materials and the substrate, • electrochemical instability caused by the breakdown of the solid. The large volume change of Si (and other active metel/metal oxide) during cycling leads to a fast capacity fading. Several strategies have been developed to overcome this problem, such as nanostructuring Si, developing new binders and electrolyte additives, and conductive additives. Here, carbon materials play an essential role, especially the concept of the nanocarbon-active materials composite has been tested and proven to be very promising: graphite [62], amorphous carbon [63], CNTs [64], CNFs [65,66], and graphene sheets [67–69], have been used and constructed into carbon-Si composite electrode, showing a positive role in decreasing Si structure degradation. Porous Si-C composites have been shown to greatly improve the performance [70–74]. Pre-existed pores in C-based materials provide the void space needed to accommodate volume changes of Si (i.e., expansion/shrinkage) and also good access for the fast transport of Li ions. Stable cycling with initial capacities close to the theoretical value can be obtained. However, thicker electrodes obtained from more realistic scalable methods have poorer performance. It seems that other factors, such as impurities in the electrolytes, additives in the form of binders, conducting carbon, etc. play also a critical role. Rational explanation of such complex effects is still limited [58]. 5.2. Li-S batteries The highest energy storage that can be delivered from Li-ion batteries with above-mentioned improvements is still too low to meet the demand of transport or large scale storage. The major problems, as mentioned above, are the low storage capacity of the lithium-metal-oxide cathode materials. The multiple-electron-transfer electrochemistry of light elements, such as sulphur and oxygen, introduces a new direction towards high-capacity cathode materials [75]. The reaction of sulphur with Li+ to form Li2S stores two electrons per sulphur atom, resulting in a high theoretical capacity. Lithium-sulphur (Li-S) batteries using lithium metal as the anode, an organic liquid electrolyte, and sulphur composite as the cathode could have very high theoretical capacity (1675 mAh/g) and specific energy (2567 Wh/kg). Compared to the conventional LiB, LiS batteries have the opportunity to provide an energy density at least five times higher, and sulphur is cheaper, abundant and environmental compatible. But the Li-S battery, as a technology, faces numerous challenges [76,77] and there is still a long way off before practical exploitation. The challenges to be solved mainly include the insulating nature of sulphur that retards its reduction, leading to low power, and a short cyclic life due to the dissolution of polysulphide intermediates in the electrolyte. The porous carbon concept having nanosized S in the pores has been proven to be one of the most promising solutions for Li-S battery to increase the electronic and ionic conductivity of sulphur or sulphide, and prevent to a great extend the solubility of the polysulfide ions formed on reduction of S or upon oxidation of insoluble sulfides [78]. Experiments using nanoporous carbon, mesoporous carbon, hierarchically structured micro-mesoporous carbon, and interconnected micro-mesoporous carbon reveal advantages over the simply mixing of sulphur with nanocarbon [79] (see also Xiao-Fei Liu et al., paper in this issue). For instance, a composite cathode containing SWCNT@S coaxial nanocables fabricated by a facile melt-diffusion strategy exhibited reversible capacities of 676 and 441 mAh/g for the 1st discharging cycle at a current rate of 0.5 C, 100th at 1.0 C and 10.0 C, respectively. These capacities are much higher than the corresponding capacities of the MWCNT@S cathode. By introducing polyethylene glycol (PEG) as a physical barrier to trap the highly polar polysulfide species, the cycling stability of the reversible capacities is expected to be further improved [80]. Significant improvement is achieved by using the third generation nanocarbons. Graphene/SWCNT hybrid has a 3D electrical conductive network to accommodate S. The conductive agent-free G/SWCNT-S electrodes exhibited excellent rate performance for Li-S batteries [81]: a reversible capacity of 928 mAh/g can be achieved at 1 C current rate with a S loading of 60%. At a very high current rate of 5 C, a capacity as high as ca. 650 mAh/g can be preserved even after 100 cycles with a Coulombic efficiency of ca. 92%. These examples and the many additional publications recently in literature on these topics show that carbon materials, especially the second generation nanocarbons, play a crucial role in developing high performance Li-S batteries. The conductive nanocarbon framework precisely constraining sulphur within its pore/channels generates essential electrical contact to the insulating sulphur, thus providing access to Li+ ingress/egress for reactivity with the sulphur. The kinetic inhibition to diffusion within the framework and the sorption properties of the carbon aid in trapping the polysulphides formed during redox [82]. The porous carbon/sulphur concept has also been applied to Mg-S batteries that utilize a Mg anode [83]. 5.3. Li-O2 batteries Li-air (hereafter referred to as Li-O2, as O2 is the fuel) battery is another option to go beyond the horizon of the Li-ion batteries. In a Li-O2 cell, either based on aqueous or non-aqueous electrolytes, the negative electrode is lithium metal and the positive electrode consists of porous carbon with catalyst. In both cases, on discharge, the Li-metal anode is oxidized, releasing Li+ into the electrolyte, and the process is reversed on charge. At the positive electrode, O2 from the atmosphere enters the porous cathode, dissolves in the electrolyte within the pores and is reduced at the electrode surface on discharge. Although in both cases O2 reduction on discharge is involved, there are some important differences, especially relating to the role of the electrolyte and reactions at the cathode. We discuss here only the challenges for the cathodes based on porous carbon. One of the major challenges for Li-O2 batteries is the porous electrode that must support the diffusion of the O2 gas, so that O2 is transported to the electrolyte/electrode interface as much as possible through the gas phase rather than by slower diffusion in the electrolyte. In the case of the non-aqueous cell, clogging of the pores by the solid discharge product, Li2O2, must be minimized. Progresses in synthesis to tailor the nature of the carbon materials for producing a variety of pore structure provide a platform to test and design the suitable porous structure for Li-O2 batteries. It was found that pores that were too small led to clogging, whereas those that were too large might inhibit recharging. Mesoporosity is expected to offer the best compromise and be able to accommodate the catalyst particles, which must be distributed across the pore surface [84]. It is still a challenge to design carbon nanostructure that will not oxidize/corrode when high voltages are accessed on charging. The main task for the LiO2, on the cathode side, is to design a good gas-diffusion electrode resisting oxidation and incorporating a low cost reduction catalyst. 5.4. Sodium-Ion Batteries Sodium (Na) is located below Li in the Periodic Table and they share similar chemical properties. The fundamental principle of the sodium-ion battery (NIB) and the LIB is identical: the chemical potential difference of the alkali-ion (Li or Na) between two electrodes creates a voltage on the cell. In spite of a larger availability of sodium with respect to Li, and the lower cost and safer operations for NIB, the voltage resulted is lower and the volume change upon Na insertion or removal is larger, as compared to the Li-intercalation electrodes. The power capability can vary depending on the crystal structures. In the 1970s-1980s, both Na-ion and Li-ion electrodes were investigated. The higher energy density of the Li-ion cells made them already commercialized, as mentioned above, while the Na-ion cells are not. The increasing need for large-scale electrochemical storage restarted the research interest in NIB [85], especially driven by the applications different from those relating to portable electronics, and the addressing of the concerns on Li abundance. The challenge in developing NIB for a potential partial replacement of LIB is related to the developing of new electrode materials. Many papers have been recently looking to good Na electrode materials, starting from structure and chemistries similar to those working well for Li intercalation. Na compounds such as Na2FePO4F [86] have been mimicked those used in LIB studies. However, Na-intercalation chemistry has been explored considerably less than the Li-intercalation, and studies seem to indicate that structures that do not function well as Li-intercalation compounds may instead work well with Na [87]. For negative electrode materials, experimental work has revealed that only a limited amount of Na can be stored in graphite [88,89]. Non-classical carbon, for instance, pyrolized glucose and carbon microspheres, were reported to be high-capacity carbon materials for NIB (300 and 285 mAh/g, respectively) [90,91]. A promising material here could be the third generation nanocarbons, especially the hierarchically nanostructured carbon with hierarchical nanostructure with interconnected pores for high-rate performance. The concept is similar as for high-rate LIB: the interconnected pore structure minimized the diffusion lengths and the carbon microstructure enhances the electronic conductivity. While this concept has been widely tested and optimized for LIB, as mentioned above, there are only few studies done on NIB [92]. This is an area where new carbon materials could play an important role, especially for nanocarbons with tailored pore structure and good conductivity. Non-carbonaceous materials have also been used for NiB, such as compounds with stored sodium by intercalation, reaction or alloying as possible negative electrode materials. Due to the large size of Na compared to Li, such materials suffer from serious volume expansion/shrinking, leading to a low Coulombic efficiency and unsatisfactory long-term stability. The problems could be solved using the approach discussed above for carbon-active materials. This concept is also valid for the positive NIB electrode where new materials with higher Na storage capacity should be discovered, as well as electrodes with a new design where nanocarbons are effective additives, coating or matrix elements, thus enabling a shorter ion transport distance and a higher electronic conductivity [92,93]. As example, Na3V2(PO4)3/C nanocomposites with an optimized carbon content exhibit an initial coulombic efficiency of 98.7%, which maintains constant in subsequent cycles, and an initial reversible capacity of 107.1 mAh/g, close to its theoretical capacity, and retained at 93% of the initial value retention after 80 cycles [94]. This significant progress shows again how important is the carbon nanocomposite concept to improve the battery performance. However, this kind of nanocomposite may require new kind of electrolytes. Further efforts are still needed to develop the NIB that could partially replace LIB for specific application. 5.5. Supercapacitors The supercapacitor is another technology for chemical energy storage, but based on a different principle with respect to battery. Supercapactiors (electric double layer capacitors, EDLCs) store the charge electrostatically through reversible adsorption of ions of the electrolyte onto high surface area active materials that are electrochemically stable. EDLCs have a long cycling life and can be easily charged-discharged at a power density exceeding 1 kW/kg. A very high power delivery or uptake (10 kW/kg) can be achieved in a very short time (a few seconds), but the energy density (about 5 Wh/kg) is lower than that in batteries. A supercapacitor must simultaneously have a large capacitance value, high operation cell voltage and minimum equivalent series resistance. A pseudocapacitor stores the charge not electrostatically, but through a charge transfer that produces a redox reaction (Faradaic reaction). Functional groups or heteroatoms in carbon materials can contribute to the pesudocapacitance that has a higher specific capacitance, but a decreased power density due to the high internal resistance of the redox reaction. Both storage mechanisms (EDLCs and pseudocapacitance) are simultaneously present in many supercapacitor devices/materials, although one of the two storage mechanisms is dominating. In this technology, carbon materials play a dominating role. High surface area carbon is the leading electrode material [95,96]. Activated carbon or carbon black has been widely studied as electrode materials. The capacitance typically ranges from 40 to 140 F/g for activated carbon [96]. Currently, commercialized supercapacitors have a capacitance of about 130 F/g (Maxwell Technologies BoostCap® Ultracapacitors). The energy density of supercapacitors in only a few Wh/kg. A lead-acid battery has typically 30–40 Wh/kg, and LIB about 120 Wh/kg energy density. The performance of the current supercapacitors must be substantially improved with the aim of increasing the energy density, while keeping the long cycling life to meet the tough requirements of applications in hybrid electric vehicles and large industrial storage. The first generation nanocarbon materials have been used as new electrode materials to improve the performance of supercapacitors [97,98]. MWCNTs as electrodes show voltammograms with a regular boxlike shape, characteristic of a pure electrostatic attraction and having a capacitance up to 120 F/g (the value depends on the scanning rate) [99]. EDLCs with SWCNT electrodes exhibit a gravimetric capacitance between 20 and 300 F/g. Supercapacitors prepared with graphene do not have significant improvement in the performance. The major disadvantage of these nanocarbons for supercapacitors is their low specific surface area. Theoretically, SWCNT and graphene should have specific surface comparable with those of AC. However, this is rarely realized in the practice. Agglomeration of SWCNT and graphene due to van der Walls interaction reduces not only the specific surface area, but also hinders the facile diffusion of ions [7]. The performances of supercapacitors based on first generation nanocarbons are still far from the needs for applications in transport or grid regulations, and new strategies must be developed to improve the performances. The following three concepts may provide possible solution for new generation supercapacitors. 1) To develop high surface nanocarbons (>2000m2/g) with tailored pore size which allow a facile ion transfer [100–102]. The key to obtain high capacitance by charging the double layer is to use high accessible specific surface and electron conducting electrodes to adsorb ions. As mentioned above, the nanodimension of the new carbon materials brings new aspects in this direction. For instance, carbide-derived carbons [103] can have a specific surface area up to 2000 m2/g with a narrow pore-size distribution tuneable in the range of 0.5–3 nm. Zeolite-templated carbons (ZTCs) have a specific surface area up to over 4000 m2/g and uniformly ordered micropores [34,37]. Recent studies show unambiguously that EDLC performances of nanoporous carbons are essentially determined by the respective size of the pores and ions [104]. Nanocarbon is an ideal platform to tailor the nanoporous size to match that of the solvated ions. But a cost-effective method is still needed to be developed. 2) To modify the surface characteristics to enhance the charge storage. As mentioned above, pseudo-electrochemical capacitance involves voltage-dependent Faradaic reactions between the electrode and the electrolyte, either in the form of surface adsorption/desorption of ions, redox reactions with the electrolyte, or doping/undoping of the electrode materials. There is a broad protocol to modify the surface characteristics of carbon materials, especially the nanostructured carbon materials, to have excellent adsorption/desorption behaviour. Hydrophilic functional groups improve the wettability and introduce redox processes that contribute to the overall capacitance [105]. Nanocarbon materials are also an excellent platform for functionalization or doping with various heteroatoms. This kind of work has become attractive recently, since graphene with its single layer carbon structure can be much more easily doped with heteroatoms [106]. N, B, P and S have been used as doping atoms to various nanostructured carbons, which show interesting results [107,108]. However, there is a lack of systematic approach on how to improve the capacitance by doping nanocarbons without negatively influencing the electro-conductivity. The life cycle of pseudo-capacitance is also a critical issue, especially forscaleup capacitors. 3) To design specific material architectures, for example, a three-dimensional hierarchical carbon with multifold pore structures to optimize the performance of the capacitors [106,109,110]. 3D aperiodic [111–113] or highly ordered hierarchical carbons are representive samples with four types of pores (micropores, with diameters below 2 nm; small mesopores, with diameters from 2 to 5 nm; large mesopores with diameters from 5 to 40 nm; and large pores and channels with diameter over 40 nm). The micropores, mesopores and large pores of such three-dimensional hierarchical carbons are generally perfectly interconnected. Under the applying of an electrical polarization, the solvated ions can easily diffuse in the (straight) mesopores until reaching the entrance of the micropores, as mentioned above. How to choose and control the micropore size remains a critical issue since, as mentioned above, recent work demonstrates that an adequate pore size is more important than a high surface area to optimize the capacitance [104]. For the production of compact systems, an important issue is to limit as much as possible useless porosity in order to enhance the volumetric capacity. Other concepts such as developing metal oxide-carbon composites or carbon-polymer composites to enhance the pseudo-capacitance have been explored with some interesting results [7], but their perspective for large scale application still needs systematic exploration. Redox reactions can be irreversible, as compound formation between electroactive species and electrode materials may occur, leading to a lack of stability during long-time cycling. The above mentioned strategies to improve the supercapacitors require also other elements to obtain high performance devices. For instance, the right selection of the organic or inorganic electrolyte is essential when nanocarbons are used, for the need to fine match between the pore size and the solvated ions. The corrosion of nanocarbons at high voltage is another critical element to obtain high energy density supercapacitors with long life. It is still a long way off until the supercapacitors can be used for large scale energy applications. 6. Carbon materials for energy conversion Carbon nanomaterials find increasing applications in the highly challenging area of energy conversion systems, from the traditional area of fuel cells to the development of advanced solar cells [114–117] as well as new areas of development such as biofuel cells [118]. The worldwide effort to find new efficient and sustainable solutions to use renewable energy sources has pushed the need to develop new and/or improved materials able to capture and convert solar energy, for example, in advanced dye-sensitized solar cells - DSSC (where the need to improve the photovoltaic performances has raised the interest on using nanocarbon for a better cell design [119, 120]) or in advanced cells for producing solar fuels [5,121,122]. An efficient harvesting and conversion/use of solar light requires developing materials with specific nanoarchitectures, necessary also for an efficient charge transport and separation [15,123]. As discussed in the previous sections, nanocarbons possess several of these characteristics which make them an attractive material for these energy conversion devices. Pure nanocarbon materials and nanocarbon/metal (oxide, hydroxide) hybrids have become attractive as electrodes in energy-related devices because of their pronounced electrochemical activity, good electrical conductivity, high chemical/thermal stability and relatively low cost [117,123]. Nanocarbon materials provide an attractive route for the construction of high-performance electrode materials, but their use at a commercial scale is just at the beginning owing to the difficulty in having low-cost materials with well-reproducible and reliable properties. In fact, not only the composition, but also the fabrication protocol employed in preparing nanocarbons exerts a large influence on the resulting electrochemical performance owing to their impact on the morphology, microstructure and composition of the resulting material [124, 125]. Preparation of high-performance electrodes for fuel cells is traditionally one of the main areas in which research on the use of nanocarbon materials for energy conversion has been undertaken [126,127]. Several types of nanocarbonmaterials, including CNTs, CNFs, nano-horns and -coils, mesoporous carbons, conductive doped diamonds and nanodiamonds, etc., have been developed. A search of patents in the last decade containing the the terms nano, carbon and fuel cells revealed over 350 entries, confirming the high industrial interest on this topic. However, in commercial fuel cells carbon-black (Vulcan XC 72R, for example) is still the main support being utilized, even if its limits are known: (i) low Pt utilisation due to its structural density, (ii) electrochemical oxidation during long-term fuel cell operation, (iii) not enough stability of the Pt supported particles, which tend to aggregate into larger cluster sizes [128]. The use of 3D tailored nanoarchitecture offered the use of nanocarbon materials that can reduce these drawbacks [123,128]. However, cost-effectiveness is still not good enough for a massive introduction of nanocarbon materials in electrode preparation as alternative to carbon-black Also, not sufficient attention given in considering industrial exploitation constrains the preparation of these materials. However, portable fuel-cell applications push the need to develop high-efficient and very-compact devices, where the higher performances offered from nanocarbon materials could make the difference. Another critical area for commercial exploitation is related to the possibility to reduce the noble metal loading (at equal performances and stability), but a careful cost-effectiveness analysis (often missing) is the key aspect. In this respect, it is quite interesting that there is a large attempt to develop metal-free nanocarbon electrocatalysts, particularly for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [129–133]. Doping with heteroatoms such as N and B is necessary to obtain good performances [134–136]. The key factors for the doped CNTs as metal-free ORR catalysts are: • breaking the electroneutrality of the CNTs to create charged sites favourable for O2 adsorption despite whether the dopants are electron-rich (as N) or electron-deficient (as B); • effective utilization of carbon π electrons for O2 reduction [135]. Heteroatom-doped carbon nanostructures with more than one dopant (B, N and P) appear to be one of the promising strategies to improve these ORR electrocatalysts for fuel cells. Actual performances, in fact, are still not satisfactory enough for commercial exploitation. In the growing field of solar cells, particularly those of the 3rd and 4th generation, nanocarbon materials play also a key role, as discussed later. In this case, the perspectives in their use in commercial devices are higher, even if these solar cells are still mainly at prototype scale, because the use of nanocarbons is essential to obtain high performances. Brennan et al. [137], for example, indicated a bright future for the use of carbon nanomaterials in dye-sensitized solar cells. Carbon nanomaterials allow, for example, to develop both rigid (current technology) and flexible cells (on substrates such as plastics), the latter being the expected dominating technology for the future. In addition, they can be easily used in printable DSSCs, also the expected dominating future technology to obtain low-cost cells. Nanocarbons in these cells can be used to realize transparent conductive substrates and efficient counter electrodes to improve the performance (especially photocurrent capture) in the working photoanodes, to develop more robust sensitizers (carbon quantum dots alternative to classical dyes), and even to realize non-liquid electrodes. Therefore, all the aspects of DSSCs may be improved by the use of nanocarbons. Nanocarbon hybrid materials [15,16,138], either with different types of nanocarbons (for example, fullerenes linked to CNTs) (Figure 7) or nanocarbons-metal oxides or -metal complexes, are critical to realize efficient systems for charge separation, for efficient light-adsorption and for photo-induced electron transfer, all aiming at improving charge separation and other important properties necessary for developing solar devices [139–142]. The use of carbon quantum dots (CQD) as photosensitizers is also another topic of growing relevance for the development of solar cells [143]. 6.1. Fuel cells Fuel cells are a key device for sustainable energy conversions, since they use directly chemical energy to produce electricity, instead of through the evolving of heat, as in the current approach basing on combustion to produce mechanical energy, and finally to generate electricity, with consequent thermodynamic limitations in efficiency. For example, the maximum efficiency of a steam turbine operating at 400 °C, with the water exhausted through a condenser at 50 °C, is 52%. In a hydrogen fuel cell (PEM—polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell, operating at temperatures typically around 80 °C) the maximum efficiency is 83% (at open circuit conditions without load). In these conditions fuel cells achieve the highest output voltage, but the voltage drops off with increasing current draw. This is known as polarization: • at low current intensity the loss is due to the activation polarization related to slowness of the reaction taking place on the surface of the electrode; • in the intermediate range, up to current intensities corresponding to the maximum in power density, the loss is related to the ohmic polarization associated with resistance to the flow of electrons; • at higher current intensities, above the maximum power density, the loss is related to the concentration polarization, due to the change in concentration of the reactants at the surface of the electrodes. Fuel cells operate at maximum power density, where the practical efficiency is typically around 50%, thus similar to that of thermal conversion devices. From this perspective, the objective for sustainable design of electrodes should be to minimize these efficiency losses, which translate in both a loss of efficiency in using the fuel (H2) and in lower cell performances. Minimization requires the reducing of overpotential, the resistance to the flow of electrons and reactant/products transport. Nanocarbons offer a number of challenges to improve these aspects due to: • the enhanced charge transport properties; • the possibility to optimize the interface with membranes and to design an architecture optimized from nano to macroscale; • the opportunity to reduce resistance at the interfaces with metal nanoparticles and even to develop metal free electrodes (thus a complete elimination of this interface). Even if the number of papers on the use of nanocarbons for fuel cells is very high (over 2000 entries in a SciFinder search on the terms “nano carbon fuel cells” in the last five years), and many claim the advantages of using nanocarbon materials for preparing electrodes, few of them have approached the problem from the perspective outline above. Reducing (or even eliminating) the use of noble metals in the electrocatalysts, at both cathode and anode sides, is another key objective for the use of nanocarbons. For hydrogen PEM fuel cells, the total catalyst loading required for both the anode and cathode is about 0.8 mg/cm2, with a target to reduce to about one fourth. In direct methanol fuel cells, an even higher catalyst loading (2–8 mg/cm2) is required to achieve acceptable fuel cell performance. There are different possible approaches to realize this goal: • To optimize the electrochemical utilization of all metal particles, since some of them in conventional carbon black supports (Vulcan XC-72, for example) are located into micropores with poor accessibility from the reactants and without effective formation of triple-phase boundaries (gas-electrode-electrolyte) [144]. CNTs and CNFs can virtually eliminate this issue, being absent in microporosity. This is the reason why a better utilization of metals can be observed, even if always no good attention is given to the fact that the surface properties of these nanocarbons can still be optimized for a good contact with the electrolyte/membrane. In addition, it is often assumed that a uniform electronic conduction in nanocarbons is present, but this is not necessarily true. Between single CNTs or CNFs in a batch, differences are present, as well as electron conduction along a single CNT may be not homogeneous. This reflects the differences in terms of electrochemical utilization of all metal particles deposited on the CNT or CNF external surface. Indications on this aspect can be obtained by comparing the electrochemical active metal surface of the nanoparticles (which can be determined using electrochemical measurements) with that determined from structural/morphological data (TEM statistical analysis of metal particle sizes) [145,146]. It is also possible to use specific techniques (selective electrodeposition, for example) to deposit nanoparticles only on the conductive parts of the nanocarbons: • to stabilize sub-nanometric metal particles which remain well dispersed even in full load operations. This is a topic which has started only recently to be investigated [147,148], but having the potential to be a breakthrough area; • to dope and/or modify the nanocarbons in order to create sites active in ORR (as discussed before) or H2 activation, e.g., to develop a catalytically active support which ideally eliminates the need of noble metals, or more reasonably acts as co-catalyst to reduce the noble metal loading; • to use bi- or even tri-metallic alloys which reduce the use of noble-metals; • to develop alternative (non-noble metal based) electrocatalysts, even if performances and long-term stability are often an issue preventing the practical use of this possibility. There are thus different strategies to decrease the use of noble-metals in fuel cell electrodes, most of them relies on the use of nanocarbons. A systematic use of all these possibilities, however, is typically absent and there is thus ample space to proceed in this direction. A better understanding of the role of nanocarbons in the reactions at anodic and cathodic sides of PEM fuel cells is necessary. Recent theoretical studies on these materials allowed a relevant step forward in understanding, for example, the role of N-doping to enhance metal-free activity of the CNTs [149]. The carbon atoms adjacent to the nitrogen dopants in N-CNTs possess a substantially high positive charge density to counterbalance the strong electron affinity of the nitrogen atom. The nitrogen-induced charge delocalization could change the electrochemical potential for ORR and the chemisorption mode of O2 from the usual end-on adsorption at the conventional CNT surface (Figure 10a ) to a side-on mode at the N-CNT surface (Figure 10b). Parallel diatomic adsorption could effectively weaken the O–O bonding to facilitate ORR at the N-CNT electrodes. As such, doping CNTs with nitrogen heteroatoms can efficiently create the metal-free active sites for electrochemical reduction of O2. Even if more precise models of CNTs have to be taken into account (which include defects, heterogeneities, surface functional groups, etc.), and theories should be proven by experiments, these indications point out the possibility to develop a better understanding of how metal-free nanocarbons can activate small molecules (O2, H2, etc.) and directly participate in electrocatalytic reactions. The use of graphene nanosheets–GNS (and graphene derivatives, such as graphene oxide–GO–and reduced graphene oxide–rGO), in energy materials, including preparation of electrodes for fuel cells, is a quite popular topic recently [150–154]. The combination of high surface area, high conductivity and unique graphitized basal plane structure makes GNS a potential candidate as catalyst support in low-temperature fuel cells, but in our opinion, the cost-effectiveness is still far to be demonstrated. In general, the preferred method of synthesis of the electrocatalysts involves the deposition of metal precursors on the hydrophilic GO, followed by reduction, because it is hard to deposit metal nanoparticles directly on the hydrophobic GNS. It is possible to obtain a good dispersion of metal nanoparticles, typically with a diameter of around 2 nm [150], but which is not different from that which can be obtained in other nanocarbon materials, such as CNTs, as well as in carbon black. However, by introducing controlled defects and heteroatoms (N, B) and/or creating specific surface functional oxygen- and/or nitrogen-containing groups, it is possible to tune to a large extend the GNS properties. Yoo et al. [155,156] reported the formation of Pt particles below 0.5 nm on GNS, which strongly interact with the support. Figure 11 reports some images of a 20 wt% Pt/GNS sample. Although the quality of the images is not excellent, it is possible to see by TEM the presence of Pt particles with sizes of 2–3 nm (even though dispersion is not excellent) on GNS (thickness about 3 and 7 nm, e.g. ca. 10–20 stacked layers of monoatomic graphene sheets). With high resolution HAADF-STEM images the presence of many Pt clusters less than 0.5 nm (up to about 0.3 nm) can be detected. These sub-nanometer Pt particles show enhanced tolerance to deactivation by CO in H2 fuel cells [155,156]. Compared with carbon black and graphite, graphene enhances considerably the electrocatalytic activity of Pt nanoparticles for ethanol oxidation by increasing the forward oxidation peak current density and decreasing the reverse peak current density [157]. Also in direct methanol fuel cells, the catalytic activity for methanol oxidation was found better than on carbon black or carbon nanotubes, while less clear results were reported for ORR activity of GNS-based electrodes instead [150]. Most of the results, however, refer to only half-cell measurements, with few tests in a full fuel cell apparatus. A problem also arises during the MEA (membrane-electrode assembling) fabrication, because graphene sheets tend to be horizontally stacked due to their two-dimensional structure, resulting in a loss of active sites at superimposed plane between graphene sheets. It is thus necessary to utilize more complex architectures, based for example on introducing carbon black particles as spacers or by using hybrid GNS-CNT supports. The use of graphene in conventional H2 PEM fuel cells shows thus still a number of issues and does not appear cost-competitive (for now), but in other types of fuel cells, in particular direct alcohol fuel cells which are attractive for distributed use but still suffer from too low power density, the higher performances of nanocarbon-based electrodes are interesting. However, it is necessary to prepare better and more stable dispersions of metal nanoparticles on GNS, and analyze how to dope/functionalize GNS to improve/stabilize metal dispersion and the co-catalytic activity on graphene sites. Another issue for study in detail is how to transfer these electrocatalysts to MEA, in order to realize an optimal utilization and three-phase boundary. Nanocarbons have been recently used also to improve the performances of the membranes used in fuel cells. Kannan et al. [158] incorporated SWCNTs pre-functionalized with sulfonic acid groups into a Nafion matrix (usual the material utilized in PEM fuel cells) to connect the hydrophobic regions of the membrane, resulting in an enhanced proton mobility and improved mechanical stability. Using sulfonic acidfunctionalized MWCNTs, they showed [159] that it is possible to improve the performances of H2 fuel cells, obtaining a maximum power density of 380 mW/cm2, higher than that obtained using Nafion 115 (250 mW/cm). 6.2. Solar cells Nanocarbon based materials have found use in various types of solar cells: • dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs), where they are used in various elements of these cells, as briefly outlined before [137]; • polymer solar cells, which can be considered as the future generation of photovoltaic cells alternative to the conventional silicon-based photovoltaic devices [114]; • photoelectrocatalytic (PEC) cells and new generation artificial leaf-type solar devices [121]. Currently, over 90% of the photovoltaic (PV) cells on the market are based on crystalline silicon (1st generation solar cells), either single-crystal or polycrystal. Prices for both are rising, and their manufacture requires costly ultra-clean procedures. For this reason, there is a large effort in developing 2nd and 3rd generation solar cells. DSSCs and polymer solar cells are among the most active areas investigated in this direction. PEC cells and new generation artificial leaf-type solar devices have instead a different objective, e. g. to use sunlight to prepare directly solar fuels, as alternative to the current approach based on PV cells to generate electrical energy (or on other renewable sources of producing electrical energy) and then use this electrical energy in electrolyzers or other electrochemical devices. While most of the studies on these PEC and artificial leaf-type of solar cells are still focused only on producing H2 from water, the effort should be directed to the more challenging objective of converting CO2 to solar fuels (methanol and other chemicals/fuels) [1,5,160,161]. 6.2.1. DSSCs DSSCs are based on a semiconductor formed between a photosensitized anode, an electrolyte and a counter-electrode. In a typical Grätzel DSSC, a fluorine-doped tin oxide coated glass plate (FTO glass) is used as the transparent anode, on which a highly porous thin layer of titanium dioxide (TiO2) is deposited. A ruthenium-polypyridine dye is used as photosensitizer for titania, while the counter-electrode is typically a thin Pt film. As the electrolyte, a solution containing a redox couple such as I−/I3 − is used. This creates some of the practical problems in industrial development, due to the leakage of the electrolyte from the cell, sealant corrosion, poor temperature stability, electrolyte degradation, etc. For this reason, the development of gel-type or quasi-solid state electrolytes [162], and the use of ionic liquids (ILs) [163] are attractive option to overcome these issues. ILs, however, do not have a good efficiency in charge transport. Incorporation of nanocarbon materials to ILs improves the efficiency, while maintaining the improved sealing characteristics [164]. Also in gel electrolyte, a dispersion of CNTs improves the electrolyte efficiency [165]. A main area of investigation in the use of nanocarbons to promote DSSC performances is related to • addition of the working photoanode, mainly to collect more efficiently the photogenerated charges and transport them quickly to the conducting substrate; • modification of the counter electrode (CE) to replace the expensive Pt, and to improve efficiency (enhancing the kinetic of I3 − reduction), and eventually prepare transparent counter-electrodes and/or on a flexible substrate [137]. Nanocarbons having defect-rich edge planes along the tube (like bamboo-like tubes) show fast electron kinetics at the electrode-electrolyte interface and allow preparing good performance CEs [166]. Graphene-based counter-electrodes are also actively investigated to prepare CEs [167]. Transparent CEs could be fabricated using N-doped CNTs (which are highly active in I3 − reduction) and normal CNTs (which are highly conductive). However, it must be remarked that in general the cell performances of these nanocarbon-based cells are still unsatisfactory and lower than the best “conventional” DSSCs, even though they can potentially extend their applications (flexible cells, more stable, etc.). As an example, Kyaw et al. [168] have fabricated a DSSC with a pair of carbon-based electrodes using a transparent, conductive CNT film modified with ultra-thin titanium-sub-oxide (TiO x ) as the working electrode and a bilayer conductive CNT and carbon black as the counter electrode. This DSSC cell gives a PCE (overall power conversion efficiency) of 1.37% compared to about 11%–12% of the best “conventional” DSSCs. As commented in the previous sections, there are a number of issues related to interface resistances and charge transport efficiency which have to be considered in limiting the actual performances of these cells. An intense research effort was dedicated to improve with nanocarbons the working photoanodes. A major issue limiting the overall performances is the charge loss during the transport of photogenerated electrons to the collecting conductive support. The incorporation of carbon-based nanomaterials such as CNTs and graphene in the anode is one of the promising but challenging approach to improve device performance. However, it is not enough to simply add these carbon materials to TiO2 to enhance the device performance, either using 1D or 2D type materials, e.g. CNTs/CNFs, or graphene, respectively, even if in some cases significant improvements have been obtained. Yang et al. [169], for example, reported about 40% enhancement of the power conversion efficiency compared with standard TiO2 by using a graphene oxide modified TiO2 electrode. However, overall conversion efficiency was only slightly less than 7%. We could remark that the mechanism of promotion of TiO2 photoanode by nanocarbons is still not well understood and that most of the results are still too phenomenological [16]. Nanocarbons do not act as simple electron collectors to facilitate their transport to the conductive substrate, and as a consequence, the contact between the nanocarbon and the TiO2 particles is not the only critical factor, as often suggested in the literature. It should be also briefly recalled that different procedures exist to prepare these semiconductor nanoparticles/nanocarbons hybrids. These procedures lead to different sizes and shapes of the semiconductor particles, resulting in different types of nanocarbon-semiconductor interaction, which significantly influence the electron-transfer, charge carrier mobility and interface states. The latter plays a relevant role in introducing radiative paths (carrier trapped centers and electron-hole recombination centers), and also in strain-induced band gap modification [170]. These are aspects scarcely studied, particularly in relation to nanocarbon-TiO2 hybrids, but are critical for their rational design. A further relevant mechanism of modification of photobehavior is related to C-doping of TiO2 nanocrystals [171,172].
