Various aspects have to be considered in nanocarbon-semiconductor hybrid materials [16]: • nanocarbons offer an effective way for an efficient dispersion of the semiconductor preventing from agglomeration, also providing an hierarchical structure for an efficient light harvesting, and eventually for easy access from gas/liquid phase components (in photocatalytic reactions) or electrolyte (in DSSC); • interfacial interaction between the nanocarbons and semiconductor particles stabilizes different morphologies of the supported semiconductor nanoparticles, which in turn influences the performances; • interaction of semiconductors with nanocarbons induces modification of the intrinsic properties of the semiconductor particles (band gap, charge carrier density, lifetime of charge separation, non-radiative paths, etc.) as well as the surface properties; • carbon nanodots and other carbon surface species may act as efficient solid-state sensitizers to promote visible light absorption. Carbons may also be doped to the semiconductors (TiO2), inducing a shift in the band edge towards the visible region; • nanocarbons may show excellent electronic conductivity, but defects and other aspects can decrease largely the conductivity; • nanocarbon hybrids with semiconductors can act as sinks for electrons, enhancing the lifetime of charge separation. Fermi levels of the nanocarbons are generally below the conduction band, and are minimum of most semiconductors. However, depending on the specific characteristics of the nanocarbons, the Fermi level may also result above that of TiO2; • due to their thermal conductivity, nanocarbons can help in maintaining more uniformly the temperature of the semiconductor-nanocarbon hybrid upon irradiation; • a further role of the nanocarbons is to provide an optimal nano-architecture in the photoanode for light absorption. There are thus various aspects, some positive and others negative, which have to be all considered for a proper design. As a consequence, there are no simple relations between the conductivity of nanocarbons and the promotion effect in TiO2 photoelectrodes. As an example for further clarifying this concept, Guai et al. [173] observed different results by preparing photoanodes of TiO2 hybrids with pristine (p), metallic (m) and semiconducting (s)-SWCNTs. Devices based on TiO2/s-SWCNT hybrids outperform those with plain TiO2 and TiO2 hybrids with p- or m-SWCNTs. Optical and morphological characterization of the photoanodes and SWCNTs revealed no significant structural differences that could affect the performance enhancement. Through systematic electrochemical impedance and current-voltage analysis, they showed that only the incorporation of s-SWCNTs reduced the charge-transport resistivity and effectively suppressed charge recombination, thus showing the highest power-conversion efficiency due to its semiconducting nature. The performance of a DSSC is dependent on a number of parameters, including charge transport, charge transfer, and recombination rates for eventual charge separation. Although the addition of SWCNTs in general improves power-conversion efficiency (PCE) with respect to plain TiO2 photo-electrode, due to the reduced charge-transport resistivity, only semiconducting material (s-SWCNT) shows the additional positive effect of suppressing charge recombination, leading thus to a synergistic effect. When the photogenerated electrons are transferred to TiO2 from the excited dye molecules, they are readily shuttled along the s-SWCNTs to the flurorinedoped tin oxide (FTO) conducting glass. Since electrons are less likely to be transported back along the semiconducting CNTs to cause I3 − reduction for charge recombination, this results in a more effective charge-separation process, and thus more photoelectrons are effectively transported and collected at the FTO terminal. This in turn leads to a much larger photocurrent compared to m- and p-SWCNT-based DSSCs. Furthermore, the effective accumulation of photoelectrons within the photoanode tends to result in a positive shift of the quasi-Fermi level. This shift causes an increased open-circuit voltage for the s-SWCNT-based DSSCs, since it is dependent on the Fermi levels between the photoanode and the redox couples. On the other hand, although m-SWCNTs are able to transport the photoelectrons more rapidly due to their better mobility than the s-SWCNTs, the charge transport tends to be disrupted by an increased back reaction with the electrolyte, too. Consequently, fewer photoelectrons are effectively collected at the FTO terminal for DSSCs with TiO2/m-SWCNT composite photoanodes, resulting in smaller photocurrents and poorer performances. There is a lack in the literature for a holistic understanding of all these aspects for a proper cell design. This is one of the reasons why cell efficiencies of nanocarbon-based DSSCs are still unsatisfactory (typically, less than about 6%–7%) in spite of the great potential offered from the use of nanocarbons in DSSC cells. 6.2.2. Carbon quantum dots The use of carbon quantum dots (CQD) as an alternative to organic dyes (typically, Ru complexes), the photosensitizer is another potential breakthrough area for DSSCs. It is possible to introduce band gaps in nanocarbons, for example, by cutting graphene sheets into small pieces or manipulating the π electronic network to form quantum-confined sp 2 “islands”. By controlling the nanostructures and defects, it is possible to create tuneable semicondutor properties in nanosized carbon particles. The CQDs can be efficient chromophores for photon harvesting and photoconversion [174], and recently, it has been shown that photogenerated electrons could be transferred to gold or platinum nanoparticles for photocatalytic conversion of carbon dioxide and splitting of water for hydrogen generation [175]. In both cases, the CQDs, similar to titania nanoparticles, act as photovoltaic nanodevices, and the surface metal particles act as short-circuit electrode for water (photo)electrolysis and CO2 reduction by the photogenerated protons/electrons. CQDs resemble thus nanoscale semiconductors in terms of photoinduced redox processes, in which the radiative recombinations in the absence of quenchers result in bright photoluminescence. For defect-derived photoluminescence emissions in graphene materials, similar redoxdriven quenching processes with both electron donors and acceptors have been reported [176]. 6.2.3. Graphene quantum dot solar cells Carbon nanomaterials with suitable band energies, such as fullerenes and SWNTs, have been used in QD (quantum dots) solar cells as efficient electron acceptors [177]. However, the quantum efficiencies of the cells are not excellent. A different but interesting approach has been reported by Guo et al. [178]. They developed solar cells based on alternating layers of graphene and CdS quantum dots (Figure 12 ). Compared with CNTs for this particular application, graphene sheets offer some competitive advantages, including versatility for large-scale fabrication, good transparency, high charge mobility, large specific surface area, and potentially low cost. As shown in Figure 12(a), this 3D assembling shows a high IPCE (incident photon-to-charge carrier generation efficiency), significantly larger than using single wall carbon nanotubes/quantum dots. This is related in part to a good band energy match between the graphene and the CdS QD that allows an effective charge separation and in part to an arrangement that maximizes the solar absorption and charge collection. Figure 12(c) reports an image of the multilayer (graphene/CdS QD) n nanoassembly developed by Guo et al. [178]. The IPCEs of the multilayer graphene/CdS QD nanoassembly are about two times higher than the maximum values reported from other carbon based QD solar cells, typically below 5%–6%. These results evidence the importance of a proper cell design. 6.2.4. Polymer Solar Cells Large attention has been given recently to develop PV cells alternative to those based on Si. The use of organic materials, including organic dyes and conjugated polymeric semiconductors, has the potential to develop low cost, lightweight and flexible PV cells, which can be potentially fabricated in a large scale [114]. Photon absorption by conjugated polymers at room temperature often creates bound electron hole pairs (i.e., excitons). Charge collection, therefore, requires dissociation of the excitons, which occurs at the interface between the semiconducting materials with different ionization potentials or electron affinities. The photovoltaic effect arises from photo-induced charge transfer at the interface between conjugated polymers as donors and C60 film as an acceptor. In these conjugated polymer-C60 systems, excitons generated in either layer diffuse towards the interface between the layers. The conversion efficiency of the process is limited by several factors. Since efficient charge separation occurs only at the heterojunction interface, the overall conversion efficiency is diminished by the limited effective interfacial area available in the layer structure. Furthermore, the photoexcitations produced far from the interface recombine before diffusing to the heterojunction. Finally, the conversion efficiency is also limited by the carrier collection efficiency. These limitations can be overcome by realizing a heterojunction characterized from two interpenetrating networks of two semiconducting polymers. The interpenetrating network structure provides spatially distributed interfaces necessary for both an efficient photogeneration and a facile collection of the electrons and holes. In this way, conversion efficiencies up to ca. 8% are possible for photovoltaic cells based on interpenetrating network composites consisting of conjugated polymer and C60 derivatives [179]. Random dispersed CNTs, ordered arrays of aligned CNTs as well graphene [180,181] are valuable alternatives to fullerene. 6.2.5. Solar fuel cells: PEC and artificial-leaf type devices As mentioned before, the objective of these devices is to use solar energy not to produce electrical energy, but solar fuels (H2 from water, methanol or other alcohols/hydrocarbons from CO2), thus to convert solar energy into chemical energy [1,5,160,161]. We can indicate these devices as solar fuelcells. There are thus two elements in a PEC or an artificial-leaf type solar cell, a photoanode, where typically a photocurrent is generated and in-situ used to produce electrons and proton (plus O2) from water, and an electrode, where the electron/protons are used either to generate H2 or to reduce CO2 (or other substrates). To limit charge recombination and also to produce two already separate streams (as a necessary aspect of both safety and cost, it is difficult to separate H2 and O2), the photoanode must be separated using a membrane from the cathodic electrode. There are some alternatives (for example, both anode and cathode can be illuminated), but the basic design illustrated above is probably simpler. From a conceptual point of view, it is necessary that a PV cell modified by catalytic centers should be able to electrolyze water to generate protons and electrons. The latter should be fastly collected, minimizing the possibility of charge recombination, while protons should quickly diffuse through the membrane to the other side of the cell. It is thus necessary that the PV material is porous, containing elements for a fast collection of electrons and realizing a good interface with the proton-conducting membrane (it must be thus highly hydrophilic). Also the other side must be characterized from an efficient contact with the membrane, with the presence of a conductive substrate to transport the electrons (photogenerated on the other side of the cell) and of catalytic centers which favor H+ and e− recombination to generate H2 (thus should have a gas diffusion membrane (GDM) configuration, because H2 should then diffuse out of the electrode). In a more challenging approach, these centers should be able to catalytically reduce CO2 to methanol or other alcohols/hydrocarbons. In a simplified view, we can consider this cell as composed of a porous PV cell, a membrane and a GDM-type electrode, the latter is thus similar to the electrocatalysts discussed regarding the PEM fuel cells, while the porous PV cell is similar to the working photoanode of the DSSC cell. There are thus various common aspects regarding the role of nanocarbons in improving the cell design. An example of the cell design in solar fuel cells is presented in Figure 13 . It is based on the direct use of the aligned TiO2 nanotubes array as the photoactive membrane. The channels are filled with a gel (polyvinyl alcohol or polyacrylamide hydrogels containing heteropolyacids - HPA - such as H3+ n PV n Mo12−nO40). The latter acts as a promoter of proton transport and as a sensitizer for injecting electrons (upon visible-light photon absorption) in the conduction band of the titania semiconductor. They can thus promote the generation of photocurrent with visible light. Therefore, it is an active membrane acting both as a proton membrane (thinner with respect to the Nafion membrane used in the above configuration) and as a photocatalyst to generate the photocurrent necessary to sustain the reaction of solar fuel production. The gel also acts as a barrier for the O2 generated at the anode, preventing its diffusion to the cathode. The side of the membrane exposed to light is modified with defective graphene electrodes, acting as a collector of electrons and a support for the nanoparticles of the oxygen evolving catalyst. The graphene layer is permeable to protons (generated by water oxidation) which are transported to the other side of the membrane (having a small thickness, of the order of some tenths of microns, to reduce resistance to transport), while the electrons are also transported, but through a wire. The dark side of the artificial leaf also has a conductive carbon-based substrate (acting as electron-grid distributor), but the catalyst, tailored for CO2 reduction to fuels in the presence of the H+/e− produced from water oxidation, is based on metal nanoparticles over a doped CNT. The latter requires special characteristics, because together with good electron conductivity, it has to allow a high dispersion of the metal particles, a good interaction of the latter with the carbon substrate (to avoid sintering), and surface properties that favour an optimized three phase boundary (CO2, e− and protons). 7. Conclusions This perspective paper, introduced in the special issue of “carbon materials for energy application”, is dedicated to the topic of the role of nanocarbon materials to promote a sustainable use and production of energy. This is a topic of key relevance for the future of our society. Carbon materials already play a key role in devices for energy conversion and storage, but the fast and continuous growing of the knowledge on 1st (CNTs, fullerene, graphene and derivative elements), 2nd (doped or functionalized first generation nanocarbons) and 3rd generation (hybrid and nano-architectured materials) has opened the door to a range of exciting new possibilities. This paper has attempted to define trends and outlooks in this exciting area, in the effort to evidence on the one hand some of the possibilities offered from the growing level of knowledge testified from the exponentially rising number of publications, and on the other hand put the bases for a more rational design of these nanomaterials. The idea was not a systematic state-of-the-art, but to evidence outlooks as well as critical needs for development, including comments on different perspectives which in our opinion should be given to research on some topics. The aim was to stimulate ideas and research on a field that we strongly believe will represent one of the key areas for development to realize a sustainable generation and use of energy, particularly the solar one. Market prospects appear rather interesting, with an estimated annual growth rate of about 10%, i.e., larger that many other types of nanomaterials. However, it is necessary to further accelerate the understanding on the relation between carbon nanostructures and performances for different applications in the field of sustainable use and storage of energy, as well as on how to prepare in large scale at competitive costs the designed nanoarchitectures, particularly in 3rd generation nanocarbon materials. The several discussed cases of applications of nanocarbon materials have evidenced some of the critical aspects on which attention has to be focused. In Li-ion batteries it was evidenced the need to introduce additional and/or alternative mechanisms of charge storage with respect to Li intercalation. The use of nanocarbons is essential to enable this possibility, particularly to obtain stable devices. In Li-S batteries the role of nanocarbons is even more critical, becoming essential to provide good conduction and stable performances. In Li-O2, as well as in Na-ion batteries, the possibility of conductive materials with very specific and controlled pore characteristics, as possible in nanocarbons, is a clue to exploitable high performance materials. Supercapacitors and pseudo-capacitors are another area discussed in detail, where introduction of the new 3rd generation nanocarbon materials with a specific design is essential to exploit the massive use of nanocarbons in these devices. Some of the strategies to enhance the performances, from developing high surface nanocarbons with tailored pore sizes, to modification of the surface characteristics and nanoarchitecture design, are discussed. In the field of energy conversion, there is also an urgent need to develop novel nanocarbon-based materials. Fuel and solar cells are two of the specific areas of development discussed in detail, to evidence some of the critical items requiring more attention. The great potential of new materials/approaches such as carbon quantum dots and graphene quantum dot solar cells was also remarked. In terms of application, nanocarbons for polymer solar cells appear to be one of the main driving force for research in a short/medium term, while solar fuel cells for developing PEC and artificial-leaf type devices are a priority in a longer-term vision. In conclusion, there is a bright future for nanocarbons in the field of sustainable energy (use and storage), but more complex architectures such as those in 3rd generation nanocarbon materials are necessary to address the very challenging and demanding requirements for next generation solar devices and energy storage solutions. Wang B Hu ChemSusChem 3 2010 782 Dang Sheng Su completed his physics studies at Jilin University (PR China) in 1986 and his Ph.D. at Technical University of Vienna (Austria) in 1991. He moved to the Fritz-Haber-Institut der Max-Planck-Gesellschaft as a post-doctoral worker in the Department of Electron Microscopy. After a short stay at Hahn-Meitner Institut GmbH and Humboldt Universität zu Berlin (Germany), he joined the Fritz-Haber-Institute in 1999, where he worked on nanomaterials in heterogeneous catalysis and electron microscopy. He is now a Professor at the Institute of Metal Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shenyang (PR China). His research interests are nanocarbons, nanocatal-ysis, chemical energy conversion and storage, electron microscopy. He has published about 300 peer-reviewed papers, several book chapters and edited several special issues in international journals. Gabriele Centi completed his industrial chemistry studies at the University of Bologna (Italy) and is actually Professor of Industrial Chemistry at the University of Messina (Italy). He is a former President of the European Federation of Catalysis Societies (EFCATS) and actually vice-President of the International Association of Catalysis Socities (IACS). He was co-ordinator of the European Network of Excellence on catalysis IDECAT and of several large EU industrial projects. He is co-Chairman of the Editorial Board of ChemSusChem and Chief Editor of the book series Studies in Surface Science and Catalysis (Elsevier) and Green Energy (De Gruyter), and member of the scientific committee of various journals. His research interests lie in the development of industrial heterogeneous catalysts for sustainable chemical processes, environmental protection, and clean energy.

coredata.dc:description: Nanocarbon materials play a critical role in the development of new or improved technologies and devices for sustainable production and use of renewable energy. This perspective paper defines some of the trends and outlooks in this exciting area, with the effort of evidencing some of the possibilities offered from the growing level of knowledge, as testified from the exponentially rising number of publications, and putting bases for a more rational design of these nanomaterials. The basic members of the new carbon family are fullerene, graphene, and carbon nanotube. Derived from them are carbon quantum dots, nanohorn, nanofiber, nano ribbon, nanocapsulate, nanocage and other nanomorphologies. Second generation nanocarbons are those which have been modified by surface functionalization or doping with heteroatoms to create specific tailored properties. The third generation of nanocarbons is the nanoarchitectured supramolecular hybrids or composites of the first and second generation nanocarbons, or with organic or inorganic species. The advantages of the new carbon materials, relating to the field of sustainable energy, are discussed, evidencing the unique properties that they offer for developing next generation solar devices and energy storage solutions.
